note.p: Located in Warren County, Mississippi, Vicksburg was founded under the name Fort Nogales as early as 1790 in what was then unincorporated territory. In 1798, upon creation of Mississippi Territory, it was renamed Walnut Hills. On April 1, 1799, Walnut Hills became part of the newly created Pickering County (later renamed Jefferson County on January 10, 1802), until the creation of Claiborne County on January 26, 1802. It then became part of its current county of Warren on December 21, 1809. Upon its incorporation on January 29th, 1825, it was renamed Vicksburg. Vicksburg became the county seat in 1836 and remains today. (Rowland, Mississippi, 858; Wikipedia; Britannica; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

gloss.p: "A person whose job is to care for and control people who are in prison, and to make sure prison rules are followed." (Cambridge Dictionary)

The Cambridge Dictionary defines and imprisoned person as "a person who is kept in prison as a punishment" (Cambridge Dictionary). CWRGM, however, adopts the subject tag "Imprisoned people" to emphasize the personhood of those who have been imprisoned for crimes. This tag recognizes the systemic injustice and dehumanization historically present in the American carceral system wherein many have been falsely convicted and therefore uses the term "imprisoned" to reflect a person's having been placed in prison, while giving primacy to their personhood and not rendering judgement on that person's guilt (Akiba Solomon, "Words We Use," The Marshall Project).

div.fw: Letter from John Butler to General T. W. B. Henson; September 14, 1870
div.p: I recvd. your letter dated yesterday and hasten to express my regret that my last letter led you to infer that I was under the impression that you were responsible for my coming to Vicks-burg. I merely ment that I was encouraged by your letter, and that of Capt Hale. I did not refuse the offer of employment, but I Suggest-ed that I would wait Capt Hales return; 'a I thought he wld. find a more Suitable man for the chain-gang, that is a man who Knew the streets better better than I did, and ^I^ take his place.

Well your Son made a change to that effect, and placed me in charge of the Courthouse, for Which I am thankful—I hope you ^are^ not displeased with me. I will try not to be So Squeam-ish; I Know your disposition towards me, and I feel it all. Your [resistance?] to Mrs B— will serve her much, and for her and myself let me again thank you, and remain respectfully and truly &c
